abstract.p: Ben Brantley article says A Chorus Line, once Broadway's longest-running musical, will be a curiosity by end of 21st century; photo (M)

block.p: The challenge put to The Times's critics was direct: Name a 20th-century work considered ''timeless'' today that you think will be all but forgotten in 100 years. Their selections:

''A Chorus Line'' was the show everyone wanted to cuddle with. This big-hearted, collaborative musical, overseen by the great choreographer Michael Bennett, seemed to reflect the solipsism of the 1970's, as it transformed a dance audition into group therapy. Audiences loved to give the love so earnestly demanded by the needy, soul-exposing gypsies onstage, turning ''A Chorus Line'' into Broadway's longest-running show until its eclipse by ''Cats.''
The challenge put to The Times's critics was direct: Name a 20th-century work considered ''timeless'' today that you think will be all but forgotten in 100 years. Their selections:

''A Chorus Line'' was the show everyone wanted to cuddle with. This big-hearted, collaborative musical, overseen by the great choreographer Michael Bennett, seemed to reflect the solipsism of the 1970's, as it transformed a dance audition into group therapy. Audiences loved to give the love so earnestly demanded by the needy, soul-exposing gypsies onstage, turning ''A Chorus Line'' into Broadway's longest-running show until its eclipse by ''Cats.''

Listen with cold ears to a cast recording today, however, and you may wonder why you fell so hard. The show felt like one big hugfest during its run. But it fed off the specific sentimentality of its time as much as ''South Pacific'' did, and without anything like Richard Rodgers's lush score. All those songs about growing up lonely and rejected, set to Marvin Hamlisch's jinglelike melodies, now bring to mind lines from a tougher musical of the period, ''Chicago'': ''None of us ever got enough love in our childhood. That's show biz, kid.''
